title: OVER 200 DAMAGE per turn at LEVEL 10 in D&D
description:
Break down of the build:

Half elf
Fighter 3, champion subclass
Paladin 2
Warlock 5, hexblade subclass, grab pact of the blade and thirsting blade

Now with charisma as your attack stat you can use elven accuracy for your feat. If you have advantage (find familiar and help action for exemple), that‚Äôs 27% chance to crit.

Now when you smite you can use warlock spell slots, dealing 4d8 for each, if you have a greatsword, that‚Äôs another 2d8, and Hex for another 1d6.

Total damage on this monster:
((2d6 + 4d8 + 1d6)*2)+5, if you have max charisma, but you have two attacks, so you multiply that number by 2.

As you can see, you get some ridiculous damage, which recharged on a short rest, and on top of that you are super tanky due to Paladin and fighter levels.

My apologies to all DMs in advance, but seriously don‚Äôt use this build unless it‚Äôs a one shot session. It‚Äôs super hard to balance around for the other party members.

Find all my free content here: https://www.monkeydm.com

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/m0nkeydm/












XP to level 3 with Davvychappy, potentially a bit a Critical Role with dungeoneering, tabletop community next to tabletop RPG, dungeons and dragons, Fjord, Beau, Jester, Yasha, Caleb, Nott, 5th edition dragons, 3.5e, dungeon dudes, DM GM, dungeon master, game master tips sprinkle a bit of Caduceus, Mollymauk in the Mighty Nein. I prefer elven sorlockadin.

Wood Elf

top_comments.author: @IstanaghVlandis
top_comments.text:
One way to get around High damage characters, or rather a way to let them shine AND keep the battles challenging is to include auto reviving enemies. Like weak skeletons linked to something not readily apparent or that is hidden some distance away. Make strong enemies spawn a 1 HP enemy in a random unoccupied space within 30 ft of him every round. It sounds harsh but what they will notice is they have to rest a lot more often. It should NOT be easy to even short rest in a hostile area, that's on the DM though. What this accomplishes is that combats take their toll once again and aren't trivial any longer.

Also you could just introduce a multiple health bar system. If the enemy is supposed to be strong, fighting alone or is a story-line enemy then just give it 3 health bars and have it revive as an undead version of itself with full HP and undead traits the first time it dies and then have it resurrect as a spirit version of itself with full HP and incorporeal traits the second time it dies. Slightly alter its attacks for each stage but don't change it's stats unless the new creature type requires that you do so.

You could also have even the normal strength lackeys and other such enemies burst in a 5ft radius emanation dealing like 2d6 damage and spawn something completely different, like an aberrant Horror of some kind with full HP and aberrant traits.

Use any of these kinds of strategies and high damage characters will get to rejoice in their damage and combats won't feel as anti-climactic.

That math is slightly off. It's actually (2d10 + 4d8 + 1d6 + 4)x2 + (2d10 + 1d6 + 4)x2. Eldritch Blast does a d10 for damage, and the extra 4 is from Hexblade curse. top_comments.author: @Olav_Hansen
top_comments.text:
How do you get (2d8+4d8+1d6)*2*2?
the 1d6 comes from hex, and the 4d8 is probably 3rd level smite, but you only get 2 of those not 4.
Also 2d8? I am going to assume you meant 2d6 greatsword and not shadow blade.
The build also doesn't have means to get advantage off by itself, so elven accuracy is currently pretty unreliable.
If I can make a suggestion, go for shadow blade instead of hex. It rewards you with 3d8 instead of 3d6, and only costs you 2d8 in smite damage over the turn. Shadow blade would also give yourself advantage in dim light, which is common in dungeons etc.
That makes the calculation from (3d6+4d8)*2+(3d6+2d8) *2 (average 96 without ability mods)
to 3d8+4d8+(3d8+2d8)*3 (average 99 without ability mods)
So going with shadow blade actually delivers us more damage as well as a build in mechanic to give advantage. Still, the only way this character would hit 200 damage is if all 4 shots crit, or if the damage rolls were exceptional. But the chance of critting 4 times, even with this method would only be 1/250.

top_comments.author: @danielmccoy2023
top_comments.text: If you crit with this build with a +5 mod to damage, you'll do an average of 127 damage with that attack.  This spends 2 slots (smite + hex), meaning if you did this multiple times with the same hex, you could do it a maximum of 3 times in one combat.  Later on, either you give up on hex or can only do it once, as you'll run out of paladin slots.  Not to mention this doesn't factor it the 73% of the time where you either don't crit or miss entirely and also the fact that this build doesn't integrate a reliable way to give itself advantage on attacks in the first place, so a lot of the time your 27% crit chance would probably just be 10% from champion.  Overall, this build runs through resources too quickly, can't nova well because you can't decide when to crit, and likely would have very low DPR if you were to actually calculate it.  Saying that it has over 200 damage per turn is pretty misleading, as that statement makes you think that it can do it every turn, which it most definitely cannot.  Honestly anyone who believes that a critfishing build is powerful doesn't know what they're talking about.
